message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Enterokinase is an enzyme that activates trypsinogen to trypsin in normal digestion. Lipase is responsible for digestion of fats, cholecystokinin stimulates the gallbladder to release bile, and secretin stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate to neutralize stomach acid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In normal digestion, trypsinogen is activated to trypsin by enterokinase in the duodenum. Lipase and cholecystokinin are involved in fat digestion, while secretin regulates pancreatic bicarbonate secretion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trypsinogen is converted into trypsin by enterokinase, which is produced by the small intestine. Lipase is an enzyme that breaks down fats, cholecystokinin is a hormone that stimulates the release of digestive enzymes from the pancreas, and secretin stimulates the release of bicarbonate from the pancreas. None of these substances activate trypsin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trypsinogen is activated to trypsin by enterokinase in the small intestine during normal digestion. Lipase is an enzyme that breaks down fats, cholecystokinin is a hormone that stimulates the release of digestive enzymes, and secretin stimulates the release of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of trypsinogen to trypsin occurs in the small intestine and is catalyzed by enterokinase. Lipase is an enzyme that breaks down fat, cholecystokinin stimulates the release of digestive enzymes, and secretin stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate to neutralize stomach acid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Enterokinase is an enzyme produced in the small intestine that activates trypsinogen to trypsin. Lipase is involved in fat digestion, cholecystokinin stimulates the release of pancreatic enzymes, and secretin stimulates the release of bicarbonate from the pancreas to neutralize stomach acid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trypsinogen is activated to trypsin by enterokinase in the duodenum during normal digestion. Lipase is an enzyme that breaks down lipids. Cholecystokinin and secretin are hormones that regulate digestive functions, but do not activate trypsin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trypsinogen is activated to trypsin by enterokinase, which is produced by the duodenum. Lipase is an enzyme that breaks down fats, cholecystokinin stimulates the gallbladder to release bile, and secretin regulates the pH of the duodenum. None of these directly activate trypsinogen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Enterokinase is produced by the duodenum and activates trypsinogen to trypsin, which then activates other pancreatic enzymes involved in digestion. The other options are not involved in trypsin activation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trypsinogen is activated to trypsin by enterokinase, which is produced by the duodenal mucosa. Lipase is an enzyme that breaks down fats, cholecystokinin stimulates the secretion of pancreatic enzymes, and secretin stimulates the secretion of bicarbonate ions in the pancreas.
